pl_output:
dark.arrays is a library for working with arrays.

  `Na`(`Vx`):       `Nadds` values in `Vx`
  `Nb`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    `Nbinary`-searches `Vx` for `Vy`, returning index of closest value
  `Nc`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes array of `Nchunks` of `Vx` at most `Vy` long
  `Nd`(`Vx`):       makes array of `Ndefined` values in `Vx`
  `Ne`(`Vx`, `Vy`, `Vz`): maps `Vy` on `Neach` value of `Vx`, starting at index `Vz`
  `Nf`(`Vx`, `Vy`, `Vz`): maps `Vy` `Nfor` each number between 0 and `Vx` - `Vz`
  `Ng`(`Vx`, `Vy`, `Vz`): `Ngets` `Vx`[`Vy`], repeatedly pushing `Vz`() if necessary
  `Nh`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes function to check if `Vx` `Nhas` values, optionally mapping `Vy`
  `Ni`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes array of `Nindices` of `Vx`, excluding last `Vy` values
  `Nj`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    `Njoins` two `Vx` and `Vy` into combinations where `Vz`(`Vx`, `Vy`)
  `Nk`(`Vx`, `Vy`, `Vz`): makes `Ncut` of `Vx` starting at `Vy`, ending just after `Vz` or at end of `Vx`
  `Nl`(`Vx`):       `Nlength` of `Vx`
  `Nm`(`Vx`...):    `Nmakes` each `Vx` an array and concatenates them
  `Nn`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes array of `Nnumbers` from 0 to `Vx` - `Vy`
  `No`(`Vx`):       grabs `None` element of `Vx`, or returns false
  `Np`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes array of values in `Vx` which match `Npredicate` `Vy`
  `Nq`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes array of values in `Vx` which don't match `Npredicate` `Vy`
  `Nr`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes `Nreversed` version of `Vx`, excluding first `Vy` values
  `Nt`:          (not yet used)
  `Ns`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes `Nshuffle` of `Vx`; if `Vy` given, only shuffles first `Vy` values
  `Nu`(`Vx`):       makes array of `Nunique` values
  `Nv`(`Vx`):       checks if `Vx` is array-`Nvalued`
  `Nw`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    makes array of `Nwindows` of `Vx` exactly `Vy` long
  `Nx`(`Vx`, `Vy`, `Vz`): `Nexchanges` values in `Vx` at indices `Vy` and `Vz`
  `Ny`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    opposite of `Nh`; pretend that it's `Nh` rotated 180Â°
  `Nz`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    reduces `Vx`, starting at `Nzero` by calling `Vy` on all its values
  `N$`(`Vx`, `Vy`):    compares `Vx` and `Vy` for lexicographic `Nsorting`
  `N_`(`Vx`, `Vy`...): puts the `Vy` in the `N_` at the end of `Vx`

most of these methods implicitly convert values into an array-- that is,
non-string iterables get converted into arrays, undefined gets converted into
an empty array, and all other objects become an array with one element.
